bioghist.p: J.M.B. Tucker, a native of Tennessee, was a judge in Natchitoches, La. In 1848 he married Caledonia Cornelia Marrs, a native of Shelbyville, Tenn., who was raised by relatives in Canton, Miss., following the death of her parents. Their children were Josephine Ashton Tucker and Mary Lee Tucker, who died in infancy; Callie Marrs Tucker; Lucie Tucker; Lillie Maude Tucker; Beverly Tucker; John M. Tucker; Florence Tucker, who married Ernest Hertzog and moved to St. Louis, Mo.; and James B. Tucker.

scopecontent.p: Papers of J.M.B. Tucker, a judge in Natchitoches, La., and his family largely consist of correspondence of Caledonia Marrs Tucker, his wife; his daughters Callie, Lucie, Lillie, and Florence and their friends; and his son James B. Tucker, a lawyer based in Colfax, La. The correspondence concerns church activities, dances, balls, picnics, musical performances, and other social events in Natchitoches; gardening, clothing, and various domestic matters; the deaths, weddings, and children of family members both in Natchitoches and in Texas and Tennessee; and Callie Tucker's visits to relatives in Canton, Miss. Included among the correspondence are valentines; birthday cards; musical performance programs; dance cards; invitations to balls and dances; newspaper clippings; a proposal of marriage from James Genius to Callie Tucker, who rejected it; letters of condolence written to the family following the death of J.M.B. Tucker in 1890 and Lucie Tucker in 1904; and letters to Caledonia Tucker from her grandchildren in St. Louis, Mo.

A second group of papers pertains to the business affairs of J.M.B. Tucker and includes documents associated with the sale and purchase of lands in Natchitoches Parish; receipts for the purchase of groceries, articles of clothing, dry goods, and other items from various Louisiana businesses; receipts for the payment of state, property, and other taxes; and papers related to business dealings with various Natchitoches residents. Scattered among these papers is correspondence related to Caledonia Tucker's efforts to sell lands belonging to the family, collect dividends from shares in oil companies, and settle the business affairs of her husband following his death.

The papers also include a collection of postcards, some written by family members traveling in the United States and abroad; small portrait photographs of the Tucker family; and an assortment of devotional and prayer cards, mostly in French.
